title: Implementation activities of SHRP2
segmentation: PRB Transport Research Board for 27 years and has worked in Geotechnical engineering, highway materials and technology development.
He also directed the long term performance long term payment performance program.
During the first sharp program.
He's an old friend of Furlan.
I can definitely confirm that Neil, please.
Well thank you Alishan good morning ladies and gentlemen.
I'm glad that I'm following Steve on the program.
When I arrived yesterday, we talked in the morning and he had invited me too.
Come to this meeting some time ago and made some suggestions as to what I should talk about.
I could talk about the sharp renewal program, or I could talk about sharp implementation.
So yesterday.
I asked him again what should I talk about?
I had brought a presentation on each just in case and he says well, can't you do both?
So if you're late for the field trip.
It's all Steve's fault.
There is a very close affinitive between the renewal portion of the Sharp 2 program and arch is and spends.
I attended the certain seminar in Brussels in November of 2007, who's a very cold November in Brussels.
And I found it extremely informative and valuable for sharp 2 because I learned a lot about what you.
Folks, we're going to be doing as part of your program, and I was able to take that back and fine tune the sharp two renewal programs to avoid duplication of effort.
So that out of the two programs will have a much wider array of research findings rather than both discovering the same thing twice, or worse yet, not discovering the same thing twice.
So with that I will talk a little bit about the.
The sharp to renewal program.
I'll review some selected projects just to give you an idea of the type type of work that we're doing in.
Sharp to program and you'll find the two of them are very familiar and their look like different takes on some of the presentations that we've heard already the last two days.

One is very much different an I'll explain why it's very much different as we move through the presentation and then I'll talk a little bit on planning for implementation, which is a very important part of the sharp to program.
Just as it's an important part of the certain program, and an arch is and spends.
The renewal program Gogol?
When listening to one of the presentations yesterday on the goals of Arch is and spins and certain.
It was almost verbatim what the goal of the renewal program is, and we have a mantra that we use it's get in.
Get out, stay out, plan your work well before you arrive.
Get in quickly.
Complete the work quickly.
And then make sure it's a project that will have a long life so that you can stay out and not interrupt traffic, not tear up the Main Street of Commerce.
For a good long time.
There are two types, basically two types of projects within the sharp to program.
Those that focus on technology.

I will talk about 2 examples of that and most of what you have heard the last two days is also technology oriented projects and then also about project delivery, project management, planning and the like.
And one project that I will talk about.
From that category.
There are 28 projects within the sharp to renewal program and a total value of $32,000,000.
That's fewer euros than dollars, so keep it in scale.
The two colors designate basically whether or not a project is technology related.
Or is project delivery related and the little* actually hide a series of projects in one box?
So that's why there's not 28 boxes on.
This this chart, the projects are organized into tactics.
This is the Strategic Highway research program.
So we've brought a strategy here that allows all of the projects to work together.
To create.
A whole that's greater than the sum of the parts.
This is just an example.
If you want to to really move a project quickly, you have to put the contractor in a decision making position.
He can't wait for the owner to run his test or do his inspections.
Make his decisions.
He has to do it quickly.
He has to make many of those decisions and that share that shares risks.
So we have one project that is actually looking at how to share risk on projects of this nature.
Performance specifications by the time you discover the contractor has done something wrong.
Or he discovers he's done something wrong.
He's long gone from the project, so it's important you have performance specifications that you can rely on.
Same with incentives, warranties, and the like.
If someone is sick.
As to warrant the performance of a project for 20 or 25 years, he has to be able to predict.
That his construction is going to last that long.
There are other.
Steps projects that contribute to this high speed nondestructive testing.
Many of the performance specifications.
Will rely on high speed and DT for the contractor to make sure that he is doing the work properly.
He won't have time to take samples and run tests.
Are there integrated tactics?
On how to facilitate projects.
Look up how to accelerate to construction.
How to reduce maintenance frequency?
We hear a lot about that.
Over the last two days.
How to facilitate responsive contract ING practices?
This is shows the timeline of the projects, and there's two things to take.
Out of this chart.
Number one every project.
In the renewal program has already started.
If you look at mid June 219, UCR, 10 or 11 were the last starts.
Those contracts were.
They are under negotiation right at the moment and after that the renewal program will be fully invested.
This is somewhat different than the other parts of the Sharp 2 program, which still have many projects projects let to to to go, and this merely illustrates that the advisory groups.
That are overseeing the activities in the sharp to renewal program took that mantra of get in.
Get out seriously.
One of the projects we're going to talk about deals with modular.
Pavement technology.
You've probably all seen either demonstrations of modular pavements or at least read the literature prefabricated payment panels.
Brought to the job site put in place.
Post tensioned, usually.
And.
Is quick is that you have a new road?
Open the traffic.
Doesn't quite work quite that easily.
And although we have used modular payments in the United States for some time, it's primarily been for pavement repair rather than for new projects.
So we need a lot.
We have a lot to learn about how to build a new road with modular pavement.
This is why.
We need to do it.
We have huge traffic volumes by the way in.
2006 an important anniversary was celebrated in the United States that was the 50th anniversary of our Interstate Highway System.
Most of the most of the roadways on our Interstate Highway system are 35 years old or older.
And we still think of it as a new system, but it's an aging system.
We have to get in and we have to rebuild it.
And right now it's carrying traffic like what you see pictured here.
So the concern of of minimizing.
The influence on traffic, the restrictions on the time and length of Lane closures, the need to maximize pavement service life, and the need to minimize.
Not just the impacts on traffic, but the impacts on communities.
An in economies.
Is necessary.
So we have to look for alternative technologies to get that through, and that's what project or 05 is basically all about.
We're not reinventing these technologies, they already exist.
Well, we're trying to invent or the tools that allow us to use them on a broad scale.
'cause they offer more control and the quality of the materials that are used.
Better quality control of the fabrication.
Better curing conditions in the shop rather than in the field.
Minimal weather restrictions on when it can be put in place.
Reduced delay prior to the opening of traffic.
As I mentioned, it's primarily been used for intermittent repairs occasionally, particularly on toll roads in the vicinity of toll barriers.
Nobody wants to shut down the cash machine.
So any anything that allow us to to re pave by those tollbooths quickly is important.

We're going to be doing this primarily through the monitoring of case studies, one in New York State, one in New Jersey, one in Delaware, the Illinois Tollway which will be doing some extensive re paving.
With modular payments.
California and Administry of Transportation in Ontario.
In the anticipated product that we want to get out of this or guide.
It's on the potential uses of modular payment systems.
Generic design procedures.
Right now most of the design procedures for these products are proprietary.
They don't offer much in the way of long-term predictions.
Guidelines and model specifications for the construction installation.
The kinds of tools that you need to build a Rd basically.
In long-term evaluation, plan to assess performance of modular systems.
This is the joke.
After I talked about the one you would not regard as familiar, but I'll bet that you have this problem in Europe just as we have in the United States.
When we talk about renewal, we're largely talking about the congested areas in Metropolitan areas.
Port access and the like.
And there are lots of conflicts between the roadways and the railroads.
Having a railroad in a right of way certainly complicates Rd building.
In the United States, the freight railroads are private industry.
There are four major.
Cross country freight railroads, and so they have different concerns about safety.
They have different concerns about cash flow.
So it's very hard to coordinate activities between those railroads and the Department of Transportation, and none of the tools that were developed.
To build the Interstate system and and other roads, United States are really sufficient to deal with this problem any longer.
So we need some new tools.
We need to respect the for profit nature of the railroads.
And.
This is going to sound.
Facetious, and it's it's probably pretended I intended to be a little bit funny, but it's almost like the laws of physics are different for every railroad.
Because they don't have the same standards.
And so the deoti has to adapt to these different rules every time they have to deal with a different railroad.
What we hope to get out of this project or some effective practices that document on how how D OTS and railroads need to cooperate.
Model agreements legal documents that.
Spell out the responsibilities of both parties.
Streamline permitting procedures.
Railroads have to get permits from the OTS theotes have to get permits from the railroad, depending on who's doing what work.
It can take forever.
On a single project to just get all the paperwork done.
Changes to specifications.
An institutional, an institutions and policy.
Just to build a more cooperative structure.
This is what's Coward's to bridges.
And we have a huge problem.
In the United States with bridges, old bridges, aging bridges, bridges that are functionally obsolete.
In structurally deficient.
Post two favorite phrases that you hear all the time.
The United States.
And what are we facing?

We're facing an aging infrastructure or facing the corrosion problems I really enjoyed yesterday afternoon's session on on the bridge corrosion and what to do about it because we're faced with exactly the same problems.
I won't go through the long list of problems that bridges are there too, because you already know what's happening to your bridges.
It's the same thing that's happening.
Hours.
So project are 19, A is going to be looking at the component systems and bridge is not at the bridge structure themselves.
We have another project is going to be focused on bridge design, but this is just focusing on existing and to prove promising concepts for systems, subsystems and components that limit service life.
That's what happens frequently.
It's not the bridge that fails, it's some component that fails the joints, the bearings, and the like.
Components should be some desired characteristics of bridges designed for 100 years.
I heard that yesterday too.
I thought we were the venturesome ones, but 100 years service life for bridges.
When I first started saying that phrase 15 years ago or so, everybody thought I was crazy.
But it is what we need.
So we need the intelligent design of the components.
So that they fit neatly into the entire structural system shows a drawing of just locating the joints.
So that you can avoid bearing corrosion.
By simply.
Putting the joint in a different location and making and having another system to hold up that approach slab rather than have it rest rest on the abutment.
The component should be easy to replace.
We have a lot of problem with failed bearings and bridges and no way to get in and replace them without taking the deck off the bridge.
When all you really need it was, you know, Archimedes said, give me a place to stand and I can move the world.
Well that's all we needed is a place to put the Jack.
The service lives should be predictable.
We can't pretend we're building 100 year bridges.
If 15 years into that service life they need major rehabilitation.
How many times of bridges?
I don't know how many of you folks inspect bridges, but one of the problems we always have is there's critical elements in places that nobody can see.
So we didn't need tools to allow us to see in those places or we need to make sure that wherever these components are installed.
They are there.
And testable.
100 years is a long time.
From the get go, you need to have a maintenance plan for structures.
And you need to carry out the maintenance plan.
Heard this a lot yesterday.
Also life cycle cost analysis needs to be part of the design process.
If we're going to talk 100 year bridge is we need to understand what the lifecycle implications are.
Anne occasionally invest more capital at the beginning.
To reduce the long term cost to the agency.
To reduce the disruption cost the highway users into communities and economies.
So we have new improved designs for bridge subsystems, prove some concepts that are out there right now.
Develop some analytical methods.
Make recommendations.
That can be turned into.
As to.
Formatted design and construction specifications as to is the organization that city is American Association of State Highway and transportation officials that sets highway design standards.
So you've already heard Steve talk about.
Turning the research findings into specifications.
That leads me to implementation.
When the legislation that created sharp Two was passed.
The legislation specifically asks for a report to be.
Submitted by February of 2009 on how.
The research results from the Sharp 2 program are going to be implemented.
Now that was only.
2 1/2 years into the program and we didn't have very many research results, so we had to do a lot of thinking.
About what types of research results were we likely to have an what were the implications?
Of those research results to an implementation program.
A special committee was put together.
That did quite a bit of background research.
We even we even brought Steve over to give the talk he just gave.

So that that committee could actually hear what's going on here in Europe with respect to implementation activities gathered as many facts as they can, and then made a number of recommendations, none of which are surprising.
One of the questions that Congress asked was should a an implementation program be established?
Well, that was a no brainer.
Yes, of course.
They asked us to identify who the principle agent should be.
And the principle agent in this case will probably be the Federal Highway Administration.
That was the recommendation of the committee.
An with ash to the National Highway.
Traffic Safety, Administration and TRB.
Also playing roles in the implementation of the findings.
They need to provide stable and predictable funding.
Congress needs to provide that.
There needs to be a four formal stakeholder advisory structure that the people who.
Stand to benefit and the people who stand to lose through the implementation of the sharp research results need to have a forum.
They need to be able to influence.
The progress of the implementation activities.
And we needed detailed plans as soon as we could put them together.
These are principles that the committee used are probably ones that Steve is already talked about.
Not probably they are the ones he's already.
Talked about.
Some of the strategies that will use also sounds familiar, strategic packaging and branding.
Giving things a name so that people don't have to think about them.
Phrases like get in, get out and nobody has to think about what that actually means.
Technical assistance.
The development of standards specifications, guide books and manuals.
This is I, in my opinion after doing this for 30 years is the most important thing that needs to be done standards.
Are the guardians of the public safety and the Guardians of the public Treasury?
Without standards, you can't introduce research results into practice.
Certainly there will have to be considerable follow on research.
Testing evaluation you already have some of that planned.
Some of that you've already done as part of our chizen spends.
Demonstration projects.
Training and education and this is already been mentioned by by Steve Long term stewardship.
The information has to remain available if you have databases, somebody has to be the guardians of those databases.
Neil, could you please speed up a little?
The last thing I'm going to mention is the recommendation on funding.
The committee recommended 400 million dollars over 6 years.
That's more than twice as much as the research is costing.
But the research only has to reach a small audience the implementation.
Has to reach a huge audience.
And that delivery process is going to take money.
Demonstration projects are going to take money.
So.
That's the end of my presentation.
I want to thank thank you all for your patience.
And like I said.
If we're late, it's because it's Steve's fault.
Thank you very much really was not that bad if I knew you were almost at the end, I wouldn't interrupt.
